qas.question: What can often be predicted beforehand?
Who normally instructs members how to vote?
Who has the task of ensuring party members vote according to the party line?
What happens if a member doesn't vote the party line?

answers.text: deselected as official party candidates during future elections
deselected as official party candidates during future elections

qas.question: What type of issues are members typically allowed to vote as they please?
What can not be mostly predicted beforehand?
Who has the task of ensuring that party members don't vote according to party line?
The independence of which Parliament tends to be high?
Which type of rebellions are common in Scottish Parliament?

context: The <a0_1><a0_2>outcome<a0_2/> of <b5_0>most <a0_0>votes<b5_0/><a0_1/><a0_0/> can be predicted beforehand since <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2>political parties<a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> normally instruct members which way to vote. Parties entrust some MSPs, known as <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b6_0>whips<b6_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>, with the task of ensuring that party members vote according to the party line. MSPs do not tend to vote against such instructions, since those who do are unlikely to reach higher political ranks in their parties. Errant members can be <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2>deselected as official party candidates<a3_1/> during future elections<a3_2/><a3_0/>, and, in serious cases, may be expelled from their parties outright. Thus, as with many Parliaments, the independence of Members of the <b7_0>Scottish<b7_0/> Parliament tends to be low, and <b8_0>backbench<b8_0/> rebellions by members who are discontent with their party's policies are rare. In some circumstances, however, parties announce "free votes", which allows Members to vote as they please. This is typically done on <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2>moral<a4_1/><a4_0/> issues<a4_2/>.
